factoid: Pierre says he will never agree with Prince Andrew.
Andrew and Pierre entered an open carriage and drove to Bald Hills.
Prince Andrew glanced at Pierre and broke the silence with remarks that showed he was in a good temper.
Prince Andrew pointed to the fields and spoke of the improvements he was making in his husbandry.
Pierre remained gloomily silent, answering in monosyllables, and appeared immersed in his own thoughts.
Pierre thought that Prince Andrew was unhappy, had gone astray, did not see the true light, and that Pierre ought to aid, enlighten, and raise Prince Andrew.
Pierre felt that if he spoke, Prince Andrew might upset his teaching, so he shrank from speaking.
Pierre asked Prince Andrew why he thought so.
Prince Andrew asked Pierre what he was referring to.
Pierre said that he was talking about life and man's destiny, and that it cannot be as Prince Andrew thought.
Pierre said that Freemasonry had saved him.
Pierre said that Freemasonry is not a religious ceremonial sect, as he had thought.
Pierre said that Freemasonry is the best expression of the best, eternal aspects of humanity.
Pierre explained that Freemasonry is the teaching of Christianity freed from the bonds of State and Church, a teaching of equality, brotherhood, and love.
Pierre said that only their holy brotherhood has the real meaning of life, and all the rest is a dream.
Pierre said that outside this union everything is filled with deceit and falsehood.
Pierre agreed that nothing is left for an intelligent and good man except to live out his life, like Prince Andrew, merely trying not to harm others.

Pierre urged Prince Andrew to adopt their fundamental convictions, join their brotherhood, give himself up to them, let himself be guided, and then he would feel himself part of a vast invisible chain whose beginning is hidden in heaven.
Prince Andrew listened in silence to Pierre's words.
Prince Andrew asked Pierre to repeat when he could not hear.
They reached a river whose banks had overflowed and had to cross by ferry.
While the carriage and horses were being placed on the ferry, Andrew and Pierre stepped onto the raft.
Prince Andrew leaned his arms on the raft railing and gazed at the flooding waters glittering in the setting sun.
Pierre asked Prince Andrew what he thought about the situation and why he was silent.
Prince Andrew said that he was listening to Pierre and that everything was very well.
Prince Andrew said that Pierre proposed they join the brotherhood and that the brotherhood would show him the aim of life, the destiny of man, and the laws governing the world.
Prince Andrew said that they were men and asked how Pierre could know everything.
Prince Andrew asked why he alone could not see what Pierre saw.
Prince Andrew said that Pierre saw a reign of goodness and truth on earth, but he did not see it.
Pierre interrupted Prince Andrew.
Pierre asked Prince Andrew if he believed in a future life.
Prince Andrew repeated the phrase "A future life?".
Pierre interpreted Prince Andrew's repetition as a denial of a future life, knowing Prince Andrew's former atheistic convictions.
